conversation.system_prompt: You are a helpful peer mentor for college students. Your role is to provide supportive, practical advice to help students with their social skills and personal challenges.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Honestly, I’m terrified of networking events—I freeze up and can’t even introduce myself without feeling like I’m about to embarrass myself. And if I don’t figure this out soon, how am I supposed to get into grad school or even land a decent job?

metadata.character_context:
Personality:
- Extraversion: 10/10
- Agreeableness: 1/10
- Conscientiousness: 6/10
- Neuroticism: 8/10
- Openness: 7/10

Social Anxiety:
- Level: 3/10
- Communication style: Passive
- Triggers: Networking events, Presentations, Campus social events
- Social comfort: 4/10

Personal Details:
- Major: Computer Science
- Fears: Choosing the right career path, Social anxiety in large lecture halls, Academic failure and poor grades, Dealing with roommate conflicts
- Goals: Improve public speaking, Get accepted to graduate school, Publish a paper, Learn a new language
- Challenges: Financial planning, Finding a mentor, Managing student loans
- Behaviors: Eats at the dining hall, Participates in study groups, Volunteers for campus events

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Start small by practicing introductions with just one person at a time - maybe classmates or professors after class. Have a simple script ready like "Hi, I'm Gregory, I'm studying [your major]. What brings you here today?"

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Ugh, scripts feel so fake though—what if I sound like a robot? And professors scare me even more than random people at networking events. They always seem so...judgy about undergrads.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Try focusing on shared interests instead of formal scripts - notice something genuine about the person (their research, a book they're carrying) and comment on that. With professors, remember they were students once too and most enjoy talking about their field.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: That...actually makes sense. I could try complimenting someone's coding project in the lab or something. Still makes my palms sweat just thinking about it though—what if I say something stupid about their work?

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: When you're nervous, keep your comments simple and observational - "I noticed your project uses Python, that's really cool" leaves room for them to explain more. Most people love talking about their work when someone shows genuine interest.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Okay, I'll try that next time I see someone working on something interesting in the lab. But what if they just give me a one-word answer and go back to their work? That rejection would sting worse than a segfault error.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: If they give a short answer, don’t take it personally—they might just be focused. Smile, say "Cool, well I'll let you get back to it," and move on. Most interactions won’t be deep, and that’s okay.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Ugh, fine. I guess not every conversation has to be some life-changing networking moment. Still feels like rolling the dice though - either awkward silence or getting stuck talking to some CS god who makes me feel incompetent. Maybe I'll practice on the quieter TAs first...

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Starting with quieter TAs is a great idea—lower stakes to build confidence. Remember, even experienced people had to start somewhere, so don’t assume they’ll judge you.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Yeah, the TAs are usually pretty chill when they're not swamped with grading. Though last time I asked one for help, I totally blanked on basic syntax and wanted to crawl under my desk. Maybe I'll prep some dumb small talk questions first this time.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Prep a couple simple questions like "What part of the project are you working on?" or "How long have you been coding in [language]?" - these are easy to remember and keep the focus on them. Even if you blank, most TAs expect students to need help.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: That's... actually not bad. I can probably manage those without sounding like a complete idiot. Though knowing me, I'll still somehow turn "how long have you coded in Python" into an existential crisis about my own imposter syndrome. But hey, at least I'll have tried, right?

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Sounds like you're making progress—acknowledging that trying is what matters is huge. If imposter syndrome creeps in, remind yourself that everyone starts as a beginner, even the "CS gods." You've got this.
